sen.j: 中島 錫胤（なかじま ますたね、1830年1月2日（文政12年12月8日 (旧暦)） - 1905年（明治38年）10月4日）は、明治時代の官僚。
sen.e: Masutane NAKAJIMA (8 December, 1830 - 4 October, 1905) was a bureaucrat in the Meiji Period.
Masutane NAKAJIMA (December 8, 1830 – October 4, 1905) was a bureaucrat in the Meiji Period.
Masutane NAKAJIMA (December 8, 1830 – October 4, 1905) was a bureaucrat in the Meiji Period.
He used to be a feudal retainer of Tokushima Domain
He used to be a feudal retainer of Tokushima Domain
He used to be a feudal retainer of Tokushima Domain

sen.j: 徳島県徳島市佐古 (徳島市)で生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Sako (Tokushima City), Tokushima City, Tokushima Prefecture.
He was born in Sako (Tokushima City), Tokushima City, Tokushima Prefecture.
He was born in Sako (Tokushima City), Tokushima City, Tokushima Prefecture.
His another name was Eikichi NAKAJIMA.
His other name was Eikichi NAKAJIMA.
sen.cmt: 用語の変更をしました。
sen.e: His other name was Eikichi NAKAJIMA.

sen.j: 明治維新後に錫胤と名乗る。
sen.e: He changed his name to Masutane after the Meiji Restoration.
He changed his name to Masutane after the Meiji Restoration.
He changed his name to Masutane after the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 東京都豊島区に墓碑がある。
sen.e: His gravestone is located in Toyoshima Ward, Tokyo.
His gravestone is located in Toyoshima Ward, Tokyo.
His gravestone is located in Toyoshima Ward, Tokyo.

sen.j: 1844年 湯島聖堂にて家老の稲田氏に従うため江戸に出る。
sen.e: In 1844, he made the decision to move to Edo to follow the chief retainer INADA at the Yushima Seido
In 1844, he made the decision to move to Edo to follow the chief retainer INADA at the Yushima Seido
In 1844, he made the decision to move to Edo to follow the chief retainer INADA at the Yushima Seido

sen.j: 1851年 京都の老儒である中島椋隠の門に入り養子となり中島永吉と称した。
sen.e: In 1851, he changed his name to Eikichi NAKAJIMA when he was adopted by a long time Confucian Ryoin NAKAJIMA after becoming his disciple.
In 1851, he changed his name to Eikichi NAKAJIMA when he was adopted by a long time Confucian Ryoin NAKAJIMA after becoming his disciple.
In 1851, he changed his name to Eikichi NAKAJIMA when he was adopted by a long time Confucian Ryoin NAKAJIMA after becoming his disciple.

sen.j: 1852年 金子孫二郎、高橋多一郎らと関わったため桜田門外の変に関係したと投獄されたが赦免になる。
sen.e: In 1852, he was imprisoned for the Sakuradamon incident for having contact with Magojiro KANEKO and Taichiro TAKAHASHI but later forgiven.
In 1852, he was imprisoned for the Sakuradamon incident for having contact with Magojiro KANEKO and Taichiro TAKAHASHI but was later forgiven.
sen.cmt: 原文にあわせて変更しました。
sen.e: In 1852, he was imprisoned for the Sakuradamon incident for having contact with Magojiro KANEKO and Taichiro TAKAHASHI but was later forgiven.
In 1869, he became the governor of Hyogo Prefecture
In 1869, he became the governor of Hyogo Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを追加しました。
sen.e: In 1869, he became the governor of Hyogo Prefecture.
In 1884, he became a councilor of the Senate
In 1884, he became a councilor of the Senate.
sen.cmt: ピリオドを追加しました。
sen.e: In 1884, he became a councilor of the Senate.
In 1889, he became the governor of Yamanashi Prefecture.
In 1889, he became the governor of Yamanashi Prefecture.
In 1889, he became the governor of Yamanashi Prefecture.
In 1896, he received the title Baron.
In 1896, he received the title Baron.
In 1896, he received the title Baron.

sen.j: 貴族院 (日本)議員に勅撰される。
sen.e: He was elected as a councilor of the House of Peers.
He was elected as a councilor of the House of Peers.
He was elected as a councilor of the House of Peers.
